column2: This species hosts the Southern Hemisphere's only mainland albatross colony at Taiaroa Head—home of the famous live RoyalCam nest camera.
Over 99% of the global breeding population nests on New Zealand’s Campbell Island/Motu Ihupuku.
The Wandering Albatross owns the record for the largest wingspan of any living bird—up to 3.63 m (11 ft 11 in).
This species is among the rarest albatrosses—breeding only on Amsterdam Island in the southern Indian Ocean.
Breeding is essentially restricted to Gough Island, with only 2–3 pairs on Inaccessible Island most years.
The Waved Albatross is the only albatross that lives entirely within tropical latitudes.
Black-footed Albatrosses have many adaptations for the heat of sunny beaches, including a network of blood vessels in the head and raising a foot off the ground to cool off circulating blood.
A Laysan Albatross named Wisdom is the world's oldest wild bird at (at least) 74 years old.
This species was hunted nearly to extinction and presumed extinct in 1949; a small number were rediscovered on Torishima in 1951, and the species has been recovering since.
Grey-headed Albatrosses are the world's fastest horizontal flyers, reaching speeds of up to 172 km per hour.
The Campbell Albatross looks almost identical to the Black-browed Albatross, but Campbell's iris is honey-coloured while the Black-browed's is dark.
This species is named after the New Zealand ornithologist Walter Buller.
The Shy Albatross is Australia's only albatross that breeds exclusively there—at just three colonies off Tasmania (Mewstone, Pedra Branca, and Albatross Island).
The entire species breeds on a single rock stack called The Pyramid in the Chatham Islands.
